update.description:
Refactor `Noise` class, and add a `GaussianNoise` subclass.

Enable users to use their own custom noise implementation from a sensor plugin by setting noise type to `custom`.

Add an example world [ray_noise_plugin.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/871/custom-sensor-noise/diff#chg-sdf/worlds/ray_noise_plugin.world) that demonstrates using a custom noise model from within [RaySensorNoisePlugin](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/871/custom-sensor-noise/diff#chg-plugins/RaySensorNoisePlugin.cc)

Feel free to suggest improvements to API and design
update.title: Custom sensor noise

content.raw: A part from some safety checks, my manual test on new and modified features went just fine, congrats.
content.html: A part from some safety checks, my manual test on new and modified features went just fine, congrats.

content.raw: Check on this->precision value? To avoid zero (if invalid) or negative numbers or text ...
content.html: Check on this->precision value? To avoid zero (if invalid) or negative numbers or text ...

content.raw: Do we need to document the arguments to this function? And what about make a couple of checks on the value of _pass_id and _mat?
content.html: Do we need to document the arguments to this function? And what about make a couple of checks on the value of _pass_id and _mat?

content.raw: Same, an assert to be sure that noise type if NONE.
content.html: Same, an assert to be sure that noise type if NONE.

content.raw: An assert about noise.GetNoiseType() to be sure that it is a GAUSSIAN or GAUSSIAN_QUANTIZED? Makes sense?
content.html: An assert about noise.GetNoiseType() to be sure that it is a GAUSSIAN or GAUSSIAN_QUANTIZED? Makes sense?

content.raw: A check to discard weird things (null, numbers, ...) on the value of "type" returned could help to not propagate errors.
content.html: A check to discard weird things (null, numbers, ...) on the value of "type" returned could help to not propagate errors.

content.raw: Anyway of checking that _sdf is indeed poiting to a valid Noise sdf parameters and not other kind of SDF information? If such, it would be nice to stop here and return an error.
content.html: Anyway of checking that _sdf is indeed poiting to a valid Noise sdf parameters and not other kind of SDF information? If such, it would be nice to stop here and return an error.

content.raw: Is NewNoiseModel a public method offered to the user? If such, an assertion makes less sense than using an Exception or an clear error message.
content.html: Is NewNoiseModel a public method offered to the user? If such, an assertion makes less sense than using an Exception or an clear error message.

content.raw: Ian, do you think that something changing with this PR needs to be documented in [the migration document](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/377e49383a2a8a38d83cbcc416ef49f6107207f8/Migration.md?at=hidden_symbols)?
content.html: Ian, do you think that something changing with this PR needs to be documented in the migration document?

content.raw: @caguero and I just looked into this issue and it seems like it happens in all worlds with plugins, and we're unable to reproduce this on other machines. Ticketed issue #1010 to track this.
content.html: @caguero and I just looked into this issue and it seems like it happens in all worlds with plugins, and we're unable to reproduce this on other machines. Ticketed issue #1010 to track this.

content.raw:
yes, I use a noise vector in order to accommodate the case of multicamera sensor which has more than one camera and each camera can have its noise model. So noise[0] is associated to camera 0 and noise[1] is associated to camera 1, etc.

The noise vector could also be useful in the future if we extend any sensors to have multiple noise models.
content.html:
yes, I use a noise vector in order to accommodate the case of multicamera sensor which has more than one camera and each camera can have its noise model. So noise[0] is associated to camera 0 and noise[1] is associated to camera 1, etc.

The noise vector could also be useful in the future if we extend any sensors to have multiple noise models.

content.raw: merged thanks!
content.html: merged thanks!

content.raw:
Test coverage for most of these changes is quite good, congrats:

*  [Noise.cc 90% - 72%](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-quantal-amd64/35/clover-report/_var_lib_jenkins_workspace_gazebo-any-coverage-quantal-amd64_gazebo_gazebo_sensors/Noise_cc.html)
* [GaussianNoiseModel.cc 100.0% - 92.9%](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-quantal-amd64/35/clover-report/_var_lib_jenkins_workspace_gazebo-any-coverage-quantal-amd64_gazebo_gazebo_sensors/GaussianNoiseModel_cc.htmll)

However we lack of support for testing the [RaySensorNoisePlugin.cc](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-quantal-amd64/35/clover-report/_var_lib_jenkins_workspace_gazebo-any-coverage-quantal-amd64_gazebo_plugins/RaySensorNoisePlugin_cc.html). How about creating an automatic test for this one? @iche033 I could take care of it you are busy with other things.
content.html:
Test coverage for most of these changes is quite good, congrats:

  • Noise.cc 90% - 72%
  • GaussianNoiseModel.cc 100.0% - 92.9%

However we lack of support for testing the RaySensorNoisePlugin.cc. How about creating an automatic test for this one? @iche033 I could take care of it you are busy with other things.

content.raw: ok I removed the `const` keyword so we'll have more flexibility when extending the noise class in the future.
content.html: ok I removed the const keyword so we'll have more flexibility when extending the noise class in the future.

content.raw: This looks good; my only last question is whether we should make Noise::Apply and Noise::ApplyImpl non-const.
content.html: This looks good; my only last question is whether we should make Noise::Apply and Noise::ApplyImpl non-const.
